author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Sun, Sun, Sun. Here It Comes.
description: Spring’s warmth is a flirt, but New Yorkers are ready for the season’s unpredictability.
content: The shift to New York City spring follows a familiar pattern: skittishly unpredictable weather leading to uncertain modes of dress. But with the rise in temperature, the style of the city often blooms along with it. It’s marvelous to behold; discarding heavy wools for lighter cottons, short skirts and even shorter sleeves. One of the big standouts is the white maxi skirt, a signal of a lightness of mood and fresh possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Its Future in Doubt, the Freewheeling ‘Inside the NBA’ Is on Edge Instead
description: Next season could be the last for TNT’s influential and beloved studio show, and Charles Barkley, for one, will not be going quietly.
content: The future of “Inside the NBA” was already a sensitive topic when Charles Barkley stepped into an elevator in Minneapolis after Game 3 of the Western Conference finals late Friday night. Barkley’s on-air candor as an analyst is a key reason that the studio show has become so influential and beloved among basketball fans and around the league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: 2 Louisiana Inmates Still at Large After Escaping Through 8-Inch Gap
description: The two were among four whose escape went undetected for hours over the weekend. Two of the escapees were returned to jail after being found in a dumpster, officials said.
content: Four men were able to escape from Tangipahoa Parish Jail in Louisiana over the weekend because of an eight-inch gap and a lack of oversight at the facility, the authorities said. Two of the men were still at large as of Tuesday night, while the other two had been found hiding in a dumpster, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Manhattan Apartment Full of Salvaged Finds
description: A hands-on renovation during the early part of the pandemic produced a place to call home that doubles as a home office.
content: For years, Elena Colombo loved the live-work studio she shared with her partner, Mark Lavelle, in an industrial section of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. She had a workshop and office where she could tinker, and was near the artisans and vendors that her company, FireFeatures, needed to make large-scale fire bowls and sculptures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: What Donald Trump’s Lawyer Said in His Closing Argument
description: The former president was taken advantage of by liars, his lawyer, Todd Blanche, said while arguing that he should be found not guilty of the 34 felonies he is charged with.
content: A defense lawyer for Donald J. Trump said Tuesday in the closing argument of his criminal hush-money trial that the former president was not only innocent, but also a victim of extortion by liars seeking his demise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Forgione Brings Its Rustic Charm to the Former Danube Space
description: Little Banchan Shop opens on Pier 57, Asia Shabazz is the new executive chef at Contento and more restaurant news.
content: Gilded cast-iron columns from David Bouley’s Danube still punctuate this space on Duane and Hudson Street, which is now Forgione; a Bouley cookbook sits on a shelf in the late chef’s honor. The transfer of the rustic setting decorated with yard sale memorabilia from Marc Forgione’s former Reade Street location was seamless, and the menu by the famously mohawked chef offers classics like hiramasa tartare and chile lobster. New are grilled Maine eel over broken rice, and baby Pennsylvania rainbow trout planked like fresh sardines. An unlisted burger is exclusive to the rear bar area and the wine list has quadrupled thanks to more storage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Business-First Hong Kong Now Comes With a Catch: Beijing Politics
description: The city, promised some autonomy by China, is trying to move on from a security law imposed by Beijing. Companies are learning that’s not always possible.
content: Doing business in Hong Kong increasingly comes with a new risk: the political cost of upsetting Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Gas Explosion Rips Facade Off Ohio Building, Injuring at Least 7
description: One person was in critical condition at a hospital after the midafternoon episode in Youngstown. The fire chief said two people were missing.
content: A natural gas explosion ripped the facade off a building in downtown Youngstown, Ohio, on Tuesday afternoon, leaving two people missing and injuring at least seven others, one critically, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: How to Fix Carbon Offsets
description: Carbon offsets have been heavily criticized as greenwashing, but they have a hidden benefit: getting crucial climate funds to developing nations.
content: The White House announced guidelines this morning to strengthen the market for carbon offsets, otherwise known as the voluntary carbon market. Offsets allow companies or individuals to buy credits tied to emissions reductions created by projects that remove carbon from the atmosphere, many of which are in the developing world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Who Is the Prosecutor Delivering the Closing Statement in the Trump Trial?
description: Joshua Steinglass is part of the Manhattan district attorney’s team that includes veteran prosecutors and former white-collar criminal defense lawyers.
content: Joshua Steinglass, the prosecutor who is delivering the hourslong closing argument in the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, is an assistant district attorney who has served in the role in Manhattan since 1998.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Travels to Eastern Europe as Russia Presses War in Ukraine
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken aims to show support for Moldova, which is under threat from Russia, and plans to attend a NATO meeting in the Czech Republic.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to spend this week showing U.S. support for nations facing a hostile Russia in visits to Moldova and the Czech Republic, where he is scheduled to attend a meeting of NATO foreign ministers that will discuss how to bolster Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Denies Limited Gag Order Request in Trump Documents Case
description: The decision was made on procedural grounds and left open the possibility that federal prosecutors could try again to restrict Donald Trump from making statements that could endanger F.B.I. agents.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily denied a request by prosecutors to bar former President Donald J. Trump from making statements that might endanger law enforcement agents working on the case in which he stands accused of illegally holding on to classified documents after he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Throngs Waited Through the Weekend for Courtroom Seats. Few Got Them.
description: Most members of the public who tried to see closing arguments in the first trial of an American president walked away disappointed Monday.
content: Erika Del Priore took a short “disco nap” Sunday night and was in line for the Trump trial at 1:30 a.m. Monday.  Joining her at 2 a.m. was Jennifer Weinstein, whom she had befriended earlier this month on another all-night line wait. Behind them was John Lamb, a Montana farmer who traveled all night and arrived at 4:30 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kai Bird
title: Will Roy Cohn Save Donald Trump’s Hide One Last Time?
description: The wily lawyer taught Mr. Trump how to manipulate people and the law, and it’s all on display in a Lower Manhattan courtroom.
content: Sitting still for hours on end in a chilly, drab courtroom, unable to speak his mind, forced to listen to people say objectionable things about him, Donald Trump at a defense table in Manhattan’s Criminal Court may seem as far from his usual domain — the cheering crowds and the trappings of wealth — as could be imagined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Is Shrimp Good for You? It’s Complicated.
description: Americans love their prawns. So how healthy are they — for us and for the planet?
content: Americans aren’t particularly enthusiastic about seafood. We eat less than half of what a Japanese or Indonesian person does. Less than a third of the average Icelander. But there is one big exception: shrimp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Lawyers to Plastics Makers: Prepare for ‘Astronomical’ PFAS Lawsuits
description: At an industry presentation about dangerous “forever chemicals,” lawyers predicted a wave of lawsuits that could dwarf asbestos litigation, audio from the event revealed.
content: The defense lawyer minced no words as he addressed a room full of plastic-industry executives. Prepare for a wave of lawsuits​ with​ potentially “astronomical” costs​. Speaking at a conference earlier this year, the lawyer, Brian Gross, said the coming litigation could “dwarf anything related to asbestos,” one of the most sprawling corporate-liability battles in United States history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jonah E. Bromwich, Eric Lipton, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Trump Criminal Trial Closing Arguments, and Outcry Over Rafah Strike
description: Plus, concerns about the dominance of SpaceX.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Shoki
title: The Story of South Africa No Longer Makes Sense
description: The country is in the midst of another complex transformation.
content: The ceremony went virtually unnoticed. On an overcast April day in South Africa’s administrative capital, Pretoria, President Cyril Ramaphosa delivered a lackluster speech commemorating the end of white-minority rule in South Africa. When Nelson Mandela was inaugurated as the country’s first Black president, the skies were sunny with hope. Thirty years later, Mr. Ramaphosa’s enervated display against a gloomy backdrop was symbolic of decline. The African National Congress, Mr. Ramaphosa’s party, has been politically dominant since the country’s first democratic vote in 1994. In the general elections on Wednesday, it may lose its parliamentary majority for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Miller
title: When Roller-Skating Nuns Came to the Opera House
description: The choreographer Florentina Holzinger’s shows feature circus performers and abundant nudity. Now, she’s bringing her experimental approach to opera.
content: In a rehearsal last week at the Mecklenburg State Theater in Schwerin, northeastern Germany, Fleshpiece, a shirtless performer with tattoos and purple hair, strode to the front of the main stage and delivered an impassioned monologue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Democrats Adopt Nomination Plan to Allow Biden on the Ohio Ballot
description: Party leaders said they would nominate the president via a virtual roll call of delegates before the national convention, overcoming a glitch that had threatened to keep him off the November ballot.
content: Democratic Party leaders said Tuesday that they would nominate President Biden for a second term in office via a virtual roll call of delegates to the party’s national convention, bypassing a glitch in Ohio law that had threatened to keep Mr. Biden off the November ballot in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: Gazan Officials Say a Strike Killed 21 in Al-Mawasi
description: The reports come just two days after dozens of people were killed when a fire tore through a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah after an Israeli airstrike.
content: Gazan officials said that at least 21 people were killed and dozens injured on Tuesday in a strike that hit a tent encampment housing displaced people in Al-Mawasi, a coastal area in southern Gaza where Israel has designated a humanitarian safe zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Wednesday Briefing: Closing Arguments in Trump’s Criminal Trial
description: Plus, South Africa goes to the polls
content: The prosecution and defense made their closing arguments to the jury yesterday in the first criminal prosecution of an American president. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: State Senator Opposes Casino Proposal in Queens, Rebuffing Mets Owner
description: Jessica Ramos, a state senator from Queens who is considering a run for mayor, moved to stop a proposal from Steven Cohen, the billionaire owner of the New York Mets.
content: A state senator from Queens moved to stop a major casino proposal in her district on Tuesday, rebuffing Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the New York Mets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young and Saif Hasnat
title: Cyclone Remal Tears Through India and Bangladesh, Killing at Least 23
description: The storm, the first of the season, hit the South Asian countries after weeks of intense heat. Millions were left without power.
content: At least 23 people were killed and millions were left without power after Cyclone Remal, the first tropical storm of the season, hit Bangladesh and neighboring eastern India on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: The ‘Home Alone’ House Is for Sale (Booby Traps Not Included)
description: The house in Winnetka, Ill., where Kevin McCallister battled two hapless burglars in the 1990 film is on the market for the first time in more than a decade. List price: $5.25 million.
content: One of the most famous movie residences is for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Leans Into an Outlaw Image as His Criminal Trial Concludes
description: Preparing for a potential verdict in Manhattan, the former president has increasingly aligned himself with fellow defendants and people convicted of crimes.
content: Over the past week, Donald J. Trump rallied alongside two rap artists accused of conspiracy to commit murder. He promised to commute the sentence of a notorious internet drug dealer. And he appeared backstage with another rap artist who has pleaded guilty to assault for punching a female fan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liesl Schillinger
title: Feeling Lonely? Grouchy? Murderous? There’s a Spell for That.
description: In “Cunning Folk,” Tabitha Stanmore takes us back to a time when the use of “service magic” was an everyday — and underground — practice.
content: If Siri, embodied as a real-live woman, had popped up in England a few centuries ago with access to her present range of information, she might have been hanged for her helpfulness. The services the virtual assistant can provide — geolocation, weather forecasts, image capture, finding lost objects and (no small point) revealing the dates of the deaths of kings — strike us today as merely convenient; but, to the pre-modern mind, they would have seemed suspicious, not to mention possibly illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: If A.I. Can Do Your Job, Maybe It Can Also Replace Your C.E.O.
description: Chief executives are vulnerable to the same forces buffeting their employees. Leadership is important, but so is efficiency — and cost-cutting.
content: As artificial intelligence programs shake up the office, potentially making millions of jobs obsolete, one group of perpetually stressed workers seems especially vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: A Final Graduation Requirement: Making Sense of Protest
description: As students in Columbia’s class of 2024 received their diplomas, many of them were grappling with what intense activism on campus would mean to their futures.
content: Standing on the stage at Radio City Music Hall, Mariame Sissoko began to speak in a voice trembling, ever so slightly. Growing up in Philadelphia, Sissoko was outspoken, a high achiever, captain of the high school debate team. In other words, just the sort of person who would go to Barnard College, run for student government and wind up giving a graduation speech before an audience of 4,700 university officials, classmates and parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd, Hiba Yazbek and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Pushes Into Rafah as Displaced Palestinians Search for Safety
description: The Israeli military said it had deployed additional combat troops to the southern Gaza Strip, even as a growing chorus of voices demand an end to the fighting.
content: Israel’s military said it was pressing on with its ground assault in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday despite mounting international outrage over its operations there, including an airstrike over the weekend that killed dozens of civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s ‘Dystopian Deportation Scheme’
description: Readers discuss two opinion pieces about Donald Trump’s plans if elected. Also: Gaza’s ruined hospitals; Florida’s climate law; a G.O.P. double standard; pregnancy calories.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Also, He’s a Magician’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Trading poodle skirts and blouses for trucker hats and flannels, decades before the term “gender nonconforming” entered the mainstream, Aunt Barbara stopped trying to fit into her Missouri farm town. I innocently called her “Uncle Barbara” as a toddler. She always laughed. For all of her standing out, for the acceptance that she demanded and received, Barb’s inner life is unknowable. Long gone from cancer, she left me two important gifts: a record of her courageous clothing preferences — deeply provocative in her time — captured in family photos, and a blazed path for her family to accept me, her gay nephew. — Dylan Connell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Maia Coleman
title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes in New York City Street Attacks
description: Skiboky Stora, 40, is accused of targeting people he believed were white, female or Jewish. He was arrested in March after one of his alleged victims shared her story on TikTok.
content: A Brooklyn man was charged on Tuesday with felony assault and stalking as hate crimes and with misdemeanor harassment after a series of attacks on strangers over the past year, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: NYU Nurse Is Fired After Calling the Gaza War a ‘Genocide’ in Speech
description: NYU Langone Health gave the nurse, Hesen Jabr, an award for her work. She said hospital officials then fired her because she made pro-Palestinian remarks in an acceptance speech.
content: Earlier this month, NYU Langone Health bestowed an award on a labor and delivery nurse for providing compassionate care to mothers who had lost babies. But shortly after, the nurse said, the hospital fired her over the speech she gave when she accepted the award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Michael J. de la Merced
title: London Moves to Revive Its Reputation as a Financial Hub
description: As fears have grown that the city is losing its attractiveness for publicly traded businesses, Britain’s government is making changes to bring them back.
content: Shein, the online retail giant founded in China, had grand ambitions to go public in New York. But as relations between Washington and Beijing soured, the ultrafast fashion company began taking a closer look at a backup plan across the Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Both Sides Delivered Closing Arguments at Trump’s Trial
description: Also, Israel pushed on in Rafah. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The prosecutors who charged Donald Trump with 34 felonies and the lawyers defending the former president against the accusations spent all day today delivering their final arguments to the jury of 12 New Yorkers who will soon decide Trump’s fate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Manhattanhenge Is Nigh, So Get the Camera Ready and Watch Out for Traffic
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 28, 2024.
content: “I think of it as astronomy in your face.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and Maggie Haberman
title: At Trump Trial’s Closings, Lawyers Weave Facts Into Clashing Accounts
description: A defense lawyer painted Donald J. Trump as the victim of unscrupulous people, but a prosecutor said Mr. Trump had directed a scheme to conceal a hush-money payment.
content: For nearly three hours on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump’s lawyer did his level best to persuade the jury to acquit his client, wielding a scalpel to attack nearly every strand of the criminal case against the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 353, May 29, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Stern and Tim Arango
title: Man Who Invaded Nancy Pelosi’s Home Apologizes for Attacking Her Husband
description: David DePape’s federal sentencing hearing was reopened to give him a chance to address the court, but his apology did not persuade the judge to change his sentence.
content: David DePape, who was convicted of federal crimes for breaking into the residence of Nancy Pelosi two years ago and beating her husband with a hammer, apologized on Tuesday for the attack and expressed remorse, as a judge briefly considered a more lenient prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: I.R.S. Failed to Police Puerto Rico Tax Break, Whistle-Blower Says
description: An insider accused the agency of failing to scrutinize a lucrative tax break in Puerto Rico designed to lure wealthy Americans to the island.
content: For the past decade, thousands of wealthy Americans have been flocking to Puerto Rico to take advantage of a tax break that can cut their tax bills to zero. For nearly as long, there have been allegations that the benefit enables multimillionaires to avoid paying what they owe when they reap big investment profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Elliott
title: Chevron’s $53 Billion Oil Deal Is Backed by Hess Shareholders
description: Hurdles remain as Chevron and Exxon Mobil wage a legal battle over Hess’s stake in a lucrative oil project in Guyana.
content: A large oil industry deal advanced on Tuesday after shareholders of Hess approved a proposed sale of the company to Chevron for $53 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Health Officials Tried to Evade Public Records Laws, Lawmakers Say
description: N.I.H. officials suggested federal record keepers helped them hide emails. If so, “that’s really damaging to trust in all of government,” one expert said.
content: House Republicans on Tuesday accused officials at the National Institutes of Health of orchestrating “a conspiracy at the highest levels” of the agency to hide public records related to the origins of the Covid pandemic. And the lawmakers promised to expand an investigation that has turned up emails in which senior health officials talked openly about trying to evade federal records laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Prevails Over Billie Eilish for a Fifth Week at No. 1
description: In a tight battle that had fans hustling to support their favorite star, “The Tortured Poets Department” outsold “Hit Me Hard and Soft.”
content: Taylor Swift holds the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s latest album chart for a fifth consecutive week, after an intense contest with Billie Eilish in which both stars released a blizzard of “versions” of their LPs to lure fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: We’re covering Israel’s offensive in Rafah and the death toll from the Papua New Guinea landslide.
content: The day after an airstrike killed dozens of displaced Palestinians in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, called the deaths a “tragic accident” and accused Hamas of hiding among the general population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jenny Gross
title: Storm Kills at Least 1 in Texas, Where Power Could Be Out for Days
description: More than half-a-million customers were without power after hail the size of golf balls and dangerous winds hit Texas. More severe weather was likely later on Tuesday.
content: At least one person was killed after another round of powerful storms brought rain, high winds and large hail to Texas on Tuesday, causing widespread damage, knocking out power to more than half-a-million utility customers and temporarily halting flights at Dallas Fort Worth International Airport
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: A Deadline Approaches on a Campaign Against Plastic Waste
description: The New York State Legislature is reviewing a bill that could reduce the state’s use of plastic packaging by a whopping 50 percent.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll learn more out about a bill that could reduce New York State’s use of plastic packaging by a whopping 50 percent. We’ll also look at why a New Jersey town decided to declare a state of emergency in the middle of the holiday weekend, and we’ll meet a legal team that is suing Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda French Gates
title: Melinda French Gates: The Enemies of Progress Play Offense. I Want to Help Even the Match.
description: A philanthropist is focusing on gender issues around the world, including abortion access in the United States.
content: Many years ago, I received this piece of advice: “Set your own agenda, or someone else will set it for you.” I’ve carried those words with me ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Music’s Most Neglected Day of the Week
description: Seven songs for Tuesdays from Stevie Wonder, iLoveMakonnen and more.
content: The day after Memorial Day — or any day that directly follows a beginning-of-the-week holiday — is one of those Tuesdays that feels like a Monday. A certain temporal fog lingers and will continue to confuse you all week: “Wait, what day is it again?” Well, today it is Tuesday. And I am here to offer you a sonic cure for that fog, something to ground you in the present: a playlist of Tuesday songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred Goodman
title: Excavating Jerry Garcia’s Crucial Bluegrass Roots
description: In 1964, the guitarist took a road trip, hoping to become Bill Monroe’s banjo player. The journey, and his longtime love of the genre, shaped the Grateful Dead.
content: Just off the lobby of the Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame & Museum is the “picking room” — a cozy, glass-enclosed corner where visitors are encouraged to grab any of the guitars, banjos and fiddles hanging on the wood-paneled walls and play. Located on the Ohio River 35 miles northwest of Rosine, the small farming community that produced the bluegrass pioneer Bill Monroe, the museum’s readily available instruments and neighborly spirit are no surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Nick Corasaniti
title: Eyeing Trump, but on the Fence: How Tuned-Out Voters Could Decide 2024
description: Politically disengaged Americans are increasingly Trump-curious, but President Biden has a shot at winning some of them back. Reaching them in a changed media environment will be his challenge.
content: Joe Perez is exactly the type of voter President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are fighting over: A 22-year-old Hispanic man in Las Vegas who grew up leaning Republican, he also supports abortion rights and was turned off by the Capitol rioters on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor
title: The Alitos, the Neighborhood Clash and the Upside-Down Flag
description: Inside the escalating conflict on a bucolic suburban street that Justice Alito said prompted a “Stop the Steal” symbol at his home.
content: The police in Fairfax County, Va., received an unusual phone call on Feb. 15, 2021. A young couple claimed they were being harassed by the wife of a Supreme Court justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Rare Wu-Tang Clan Album to Be Played at Exhibit in Tasmania
description: The sole known copy of the album “Once Upon a Time in Shaolin” was not to be heard by the public until 2103. Some fans will be able to hear a selection of the 31 tracks at a museum in Hobart, Tasmania.
content: A decade ago, the Wu-Tang Clan issued a sole copy of a CD-only album, secured it in an engraved nickel and silver box, locked it away in a vault and said it could not be heard by the public until 2103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Who Plotted to Sell Graceland? An Identity Thief Raises His Hand.
description: A person using an email for the company seeking to foreclose on the former home of Elvis Presley says his ring was behind the threat to sell the beloved landmark.
content: The writer said he was an identity thief — a ring leader on the dark web, with a network of “worms” placed throughout the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Sue Johnson, Psychologist Who Took a Scientific View of Love, Dies at 76
description: She believed the bond between adults was as sustaining as that between parent and child, and developed a therapy to strengthen and repair broken relationships.
content: Sue Johnson, a British-born Canadian clinical psychologist and best-selling author who developed a novel method of couples therapy based on emotional attachment, challenging what had been the dominant behavioral approach — the idea that behaviors are learned and thus can be changed — died on April 23 in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Feldman and Alison Simmons
title: Harvard Should Say Less. Maybe All Schools Should.
description: Let’s spare universities from having to decide which world events deserve official statements.
content: Last fall, Harvard University’s leadership found itself at the center of a highly public, highly charged fight about taking an official institutional position in connection with the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel and the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Calls Mount to Let Ukraine Strike Russia With Western Weapons
description: The U.S. and other allies have banned Ukraine from firing Western weapons into Russia. Kyiv says that has handcuffed its ability to prevent cross-border attacks.
content: Western nations are stepping up their calls to allow attacks on Russian territory using weapons that they have sent the Ukrainian military — an issue that is taking on greater urgency as Russia builds up troops on the border in preparation for a possible offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Leaflet by Leaflet, a Few Aging Activists Fight India’s Tide of Bigotry
description: As politicians stoke religious hatred online, these veterans of social causes deliver their messages in person: “Talk to each other. Don’t let anyone divide you.”
content: One recent morning, Roop Rekha Verma, an 80-year-old peace activist and former university leader, walked through a north Indian neighborhood prone to sectarian strife and parked herself near a tea shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer
title: The Untold Story of the Network That Took Down Roe v. Wade
description: A conservative Christian coalition’s plan to end the federal right to abortion began just days after Trump’s 2016 election.
content: It happened almost by accident, over cocktails. Exactly the kind of accident that Leonard Leo intended to happen at his Federalist Society’s annual conference — a three-day gathering of the conservative tribe and a strategy session for right-wing lawyers, officials and judges that drew both big names and those who had lower profiles but were no less ambitious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phil Buehler and Steve Siegel
title: In 1974, Two Film Students Rowed to Ellis Island. Here’s What They Captured.
description: In the early 1970s, two high school filmmakers ventured out in a rowboat to make a 16 mm film about an abandoned space nearby: Ellis Island.
content: Ellis Island in New York Harbor served as the principal point of entry for immigrants arriving in the United States from 1892 through 1924, and was used for detention and deportation until its closing in 1954. All in all, over 12 million immigrants passed through its halls. But by 1974, when we were students and made the short documentary above, it was in decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Joao Silva
title: South Africa’s Young Democracy Leaves Its Young Voters Disillusioned
description: We spoke to South Africans who grew up in the three decades since the country overthrew apartheid and held its first free election about their lives and plans to vote — or not — in this week's pivotal election.
content: At the dawn of South Africa’s democracy after the fall of the racist apartheid government, millions lined up before sunrise to cast their ballots in the country’s first free and fair election in 1994.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: What We Know About the Papua New Guinea Landslide
description: Nearly five days after the disaster hit a remote section of the country, officials have started evacuating residents. But the scale of the death toll remains uncertain.
content: Nearly five days after a landslide devastated a remote section of Papua New Guinea, officials in the Pacific Island nation have begun evacuating residents, because the area remains unsafe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Three European Countries Formally Recognize Palestinian Statehood
description: The moves are a rebuke to Israel, who is the face of mounting international anger over the country’s military offensive in Gaza.
content: Three European nations formally recognized an independent Palestinian state on Tuesday, drawing the ire of Israel as it continued to press its military offensive in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Carbon Offsets, a Much-Criticized Climate Tool, Get Federal Guidelines
description: The new principles aim to define ‘high-integrity’ offsets amid concerns that current practices often don’t cut greenhouse gas emissions as claimed.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday laid out for the first time a set of broad government guidelines around the use of carbon offsets in an attempt to shore up confidence in a method for tackling global warming that has faced growing criticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Michigan Trooper Charged With Murder in Death of Fleeing Man
description: Detective Sgt. Brian Keely was charged in the death of Samuel Sterling, who was fatally struck by an unmarked police S.U.V. in suburban Grand Rapids last month.
content: The Michigan attorney general charged a state trooper with murder on Tuesday, saying he was “grossly negligent” when he fatally struck a fleeing man, Samuel Sterling, with a vehicle last month in suburban Grand Rapids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
title: If Trump Is Convicted, How Will Biden’s Team Go on the Attack?
description: A guilty verdict in New York would be a gift for Democrats — but if it comes, the Biden campaign is unlikely to tear up its 2024 playbook.
content: Normally, seeing your presidential opponent convicted of a felony would be a cause for celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: BuzzFeed Clashes With Vivek Ramaswamy
description: The former G.O.P. presidential candidate, who has invested in BuzzFeed, believes the company needs to pivot. He wants to see commentators like Tucker Carlson in its lineup.
content: BuzzFeed’s newest activist investor, the former Republican presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy, wants the company to consider moves like hiring the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson and the N.B.A. commentator Charles Barkley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,075, May 29, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: War-Weary Iraqis Feel for Gaza, but Fear Spread of the Conflict
description: Iraqis want to help Palestinians but say they are still recovering from their own wars and fear playing host to a proxy fight between Iran and the United States.
content: Iraqis have known the bitter taste of war so intimately and frequently over the past 40 years that they say they can feel viscerally the suffering of Palestinians in Gaza. They remember the dreaded whistling of a shell before impact, the fear of a knock at the door bringing word of a loved one’s loss, the stench of blood drying on concrete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: Five New Hotels and Spas Built for Bathing
description: From southern Japan to the English countryside, these properties put the focus on therapeutic waters.
content: In the ever-expanding wellness world, one of the latest trends is actually one of the oldest: soaking in, and sometimes drinking, therapeutic waters. In ancient Greece, physicians, including Hippocrates, prescribed mineral-rich baths to treat everything from skin diseases to insomnia. (According to one theory, the word “spa” is an acronym of the Latin phrase “sanus per aqua,” meaning “health by water.”) The practice has also been employed in Asia since at least the sixth century A.D., when nomadic Buddhists are said to have brought the concept of onsen (inns and bathhouses built around natural geothermal pools) to Japan from the Korean Peninsula. Now, with various forms of hydrotherapy, such as cold plunges and steam saunas, making a comeback, wellness entrepreneurs are debuting properties centered on bathing. Here, five places to take a dip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Have You Enrolled in Georgia’s Medicaid Work Requirement Program? We’d Like to Hear From You.
description: We’re hoping to speak with people who have tried enrolling in or have been covered by Georgia Pathways, the Medicaid work requirement program. We want to know what the experience was like.
content: Last year, Georgia began a program called Pathways to Coverage, which allows lower-income residents to secure Medicaid health insurance if they complete 80 hours each month of professional, academic or community activities. People who are working part- or full-time, have completed community service or are pursuing a college education can qualify, and can mix the different activities to be eligible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Trump’s Trial Has Entered Its Final Stages. Here’s What Comes Next.
description: In the seventh week of trial, closing arguments will be made and the jury will start deliberations.
content: Closing arguments start Tuesday in the Manhattan hush-money trial of Donald J. Trump, signaling the final stages of the first criminal trial of an American president. Both prosecutors and defense lawyers will make their final cases for his guilt or innocence before jurors deliberate Mr. Trump’s fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Nate Schweber, Neil Vigdor and Michael Gold
title: Robert De Niro, as Biden Surrogate, Says Trump ‘Absolutely’ Should Go to Jail
description: Seeking to troll Donald Trump outside his Manhattan trial, the Biden campaign held a news conference with the actor and two former Capitol Police officers. Mr. De Niro veered off script.
content: President Biden’s campaign, after more than a year of studiously avoiding direct comments about Donald J. Trump’s legal problems, on Tuesday dispatched the actor Robert De Niro to the Manhattan courthouse where the former president’s first criminal trial is wrapping up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 100 Easy Summer Recipes for Right Now
description: Breezy and adaptable, most of these dishes can be on the table in 30 minutes or less.
content: More fun, less drudgery. That’s my goal for the summer — and specifically for my summer cooking. In my dreams, I’m whisking together a vinaigrette in a seaside cottage with a big breezy kitchen and a farm stand down the road (think Diane Keaton’s place in “Something’s Gotta Give”). While that’s not the reality for most of us — myself included — you can still welcome that relaxed sensibility in the recipes you cook and how you cook them (barefoot, good music playing, windows thrown open — or the A.C. on full blast).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Climate Change Added a Month’s Worth of Extra-Hot Days in Past Year
description: Since last May, the average person experienced 26 more days of abnormal warmth than they would have without global warming, a new analysis found.
content: Over the past year of record-shattering warmth, the average person on Earth experienced 26 more days of abnormally high temperatures than they otherwise would have, were it not for human-induced climate change, scientists said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Pier for Gaza Aid Damaged by Rough Seas
description: Army engineers are working to put the pier back together, and Defense Department officials hope it will be operational again in about a week.
content: The temporary pier that the U.S. military constructed and put in place to provide much-needed humanitarian aid for Gaza has broken apart in rough seas, the Pentagon said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Murphy
title: A 20-Minute Intense Workout That’s Easy on Your Joints
description: HIIT routines are typically both high intensity and high impact. But you can still get the hard work while being easy on your body.
content: High-intensity workouts are designed to be hard. The whole point of repeatedly going all out for 30 seconds or a minute at a time is to get the maximum cardiovascular exercise in the least amount of time. But that doesn’t mean these workouts need to be punishing for your joints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Do We Still Understand How Wars Are Won?
description: Israel and Ukraine don’t have the luxury of fighting fecklessly.
content: In the past 50 years, the United States has gotten good at losing wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Say Hello to Our Summer 100
description: The 100 recipes (shrimp scampi with tomatoes and corn, watermelon chaat, perfect peach cobbler) to cook on repeat all summer.
content: Summer is the best of time of year to cook and eat, by far, with its hissing grills, saltwater-seasoned beach picnics, stone fruit dripping with juice, vine vegetables brimming with flavor and pastel cones of melting ice cream. I love it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: The 15 Most Unforgettable Looks From Cannes
description: The festival is over, but the style is here to stay.
content: The Cannes Festival jury led by Greta Gerwig announced its winners this weekend, including the Palme d’Or for “Anora,” a comedy from the American filmmaker Sean Baker about a sex worker who marries the son of a Russian oligarch. The ceremony concluded 10 full days filled with movies and long ovations, news conferences peppered with politics, a filmmaker’s return, women-led films that caused a stir, a president’s origin story and, of course, canine stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: When Reporters Need a Voice, Sometimes They Ask the Crowd
description: Reader callouts are like fliers on a digital bulletin board. They help journalists find sources — and discover stories they didn’t know they were looking for.
content: Every day, New York Times reporters knock on doors and make phone calls to find stories. They spend hours, weeks and months on old-fashioned, boots-on-the-ground reporting. But a reader callout — an online form designed to elicit responses from certain people — can do what no other tool in the reporting tool belt can. Like a flier on a bulletin board or an advertisement that asks “Has this happened to you?,” a callout helps reporters reach many more people at once and find just the right source for their story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Bill Walton’s Long, Special Relationship With the Grateful Dead
description: “It wasn’t like he was a fan,” the drummer Mickey Hart said. “He was part of our family.”
content: Bill Walton played 604 basketball games in college and the N.B.A. over the course of his Hall of Fame career. But Walton, who died Monday from cancer at 71, wrote in a 2016 autobiography that he had attended more than 869 concerts by his most beloved musical act, the Grateful Dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How We’ve Lost Our Moorings as a Society
description: Our society is losing sight of qualities that kept America strong, like responsibility and civility but also the capacity to feel shame.
content: The conventional wisdom is that Donald Trump’s trial over his alleged efforts to buy the silence of a porn star on the eve of the 2016 election is the least important of the cases against him. Politically that may be true. But more than any of the other cases, this one is revealing of a trend ailing America today: how much we’ve lost our moorings as a society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Call Me Your Darling Angel
description: This Tuesday debut puzzle is full of fun facts.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Rudnick
title: Divorced, Disheveled and Hiking Toward Love
description: In David Nicholls’s “You Are Here,” a boggy trek through the English countryside becomes an unlikely impetus for midlife romance.
content: David Nicholls’s captivating new novel takes place almost entirely during a guided, days-long walk through the English countryside, past perilous crags, moors and villages with names like Buttermere, Honister Pass and Bolton-on-Swale. In lesser hands, “You Are Here” might be a literal slog, but Nicholls has fashioned an ideal structure for an affectingly hard-won romance, a genre he has honed as the author of many best sellers, including the much loved and repeatedly adapted “One Day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: How the Tree Lobster Escaped Extinction
description: The Lord Howe Island stick insect vanished from its home, but an effort at zoos in San Diego and Melbourne highlights the possibilities and challenges of conserving invertebrate animals.
content: The feisty Lord Howe Island stick insect crawling on the gloved hand of Kyle Kassel, a keeper at the San Diego Zoo, had no idea that he shouldn’t exist. The intrepid insect, nicknamed a tree lobster because some grow to eight inches, seemed determined to prevent me from snapping a good picture as he raced about Mr. Kassel’s hands like a dog with the zoomies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Harvard Says It Will No Longer Take Positions on Matters Outside of the University
description: The policy could ease pressure on the school to issue statements on current events. Officials were criticized for their handling of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.
content: Harvard said on Tuesday that it would now avoid taking positions on matters that are not “relevant to the core function of the university,” accepting the recommendations of a faculty committee that urged the university to dramatically reduce its messages on issues of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Waldman
title: We Can Turn a River in Maine Into a Paradise for Salmon
description: Currently, the fish are blocked from their most important spawning tributary.
content: In his 1937 book, “Kennebec: Cradle of Americans,” the poet Robert Tristram Coffin called Maine’s sprawling river a “paradise for fish.” But pollution and dams that block spawning runs for Atlantic salmon, sturgeon and shad put an end to that world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Here are the other Texas runoff elections we’re watching.
description: Representative Tony Gonzales is facing a challenge from a gun rights activist.
content: Texans voted on Tuesday in runoff elections for a number of offices, with a competitive primary race in Southwest Texas currently too close to call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: What Is the ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape, and How Does It Factor Into Trump’s Trial?
description: Prosecutors have mentioned the tape at various stages of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, including during closing arguments on Tuesday.
content: About a month before Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, a recording surfaced of him speaking in vulgar terms about women, causing a crisis within the Trump campaign and pandemonium across the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: Congestion Pricing Could Bring Cleaner Air. But Maybe Not for Everyone.
description: Officials expect New York City’s new tolling system to reduce air pollution, as well as carbon emissions. The impact may be uneven.
content: When congestion pricing takes effect in New York City next month, officials say it will create an array of benefits: The system’s tolls will generate revenue for improving mass transit while prompting some drivers to avoid Manhattan, potentially reducing traffic and air pollution, as well as carbon emissions that contribute to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Closing Arguments Are Coming in Trump’s Trial. Here’s How They Work.
description: Each side will have an opportunity to summarize its case before the jury begins to deliberate.
content: After five grueling weeks of testimony, prosecutors and defense lawyers will have one final chance to sway the 12 jurors in the Manhattan criminal trial of Donald J. Trump: closing arguments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: R.F.K. Jr. Denounces the Removal of Confederate Statues
description: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said on a recent podcast that he had a “visceral reaction” to the removal of statues glorifying Confederate leaders.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. denounced the removal of hundreds of Confederate statues and other monuments across the United States after the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Top FTX Executive Sentenced to 7½ Years in Prison
description: Ryan Salame, the head of FTX’s subsidiary in the Bahamas, was the first of Sam Bankman-Fried’s deputies to be sentenced since the crypto exchange collapsed in November 2022.
content: Ryan Salame, a top executive at the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison on Tuesday, making him the first of Sam Bankman-Fried’s circle of advisers at FTX to receive prison time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: The Man Behind the Effortless, Viral Grooves
description: Shay Latukolan, who has worked with Jungle and Childish Gambino, creates choreography so infectious that everyone thinks they can dance along.
content: Dancers sometimes talk about finding the pocket — a kind of flow state where rhythm and movement are so perfectly married that the dancing is not just on the music, but in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams
title: Biden Moves to Open U.S. Banks to Cuba’s Private Sector
description: The rules will allow Cuban entrepreneurs to open bank accounts in the United States, making it easier for them to expand and encouraging other Cubans to start businesses.
content: The Biden administration, in a major move to support Cuba’s expanding private sector, announced on Tuesday new regulations allowing Cuban entrepreneurs on the island to open bank accounts in the United States for the first time and to make remote online transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: amiable
description: This word has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word amiable has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 12 in the obituary “Olga Murray, Who Changed the Lives of Children in Nepal, Dies at 98” by Richard Sandomir:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Wizard of Jeans
description: Benjamin Talley Smith may well have made the jeans in your closet. And your friend’s closet. And your friend’s friends’.
content: One overcast Sunday morning, Benjamin Talley Smith, an apple-cheeked 45-year-old with a thing for a Canadian tuxedo, was at the Rose Bowl flea market in Los Angeles shopping for jeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: On the Dangers of Inflation Brain
description: Is the Fed, among others, focused on the wrong problem?
content: Surging prices in 2021-22, after decades of low inflation, came as a shock to many. So it was in a way understandable that many observers more or less freaked out, seeing a return to the 1970s lurking under every bed and behind every closet door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: U.S. Officials Say Deadly Rafah Airstrike Did Not Cross Biden’s Red Line
description: The deaths were “devastating,” a White House spokesman said, but the scale of the attack was not enough to change U.S. policy.
content: U.S. officials said on Tuesday that the Israeli strike that killed dozens of Palestinians in southern Gaza was a tragedy but that it did not violate President Biden’s red line for withholding weapons shipments to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Patricia Mazzei
title: Marco Rubio Wants to Be Trump’s Vice President. He Doesn’t Want to Audition.
description: The last time the Florida senator lived in Donald J. Trump’s orbit he was mocked and defeated. As he returns, he’s trying to do it on his terms.
content: Senator Marco Rubio, the Republican of Florida, has not visited the courthouse in Manhattan to flaunt his support for Donald J. Trump like other potential running mates. He is not a fixture at the former president’s campaign rallies and has not become part of the furniture at Mar-a-Lago, like other Republicans craving relevancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Says It Has Begun Training a New Flagship A.I. Model
description: The advanced A.I. system would succeed GPT-4, which powers ChatGPT. The company has also created a new safety committee to address A.I.’s risks.
content: OpenAI said on Tuesday that it had begun training a new flagship artificial intelligence model that would succeed the GPT-4 technology that drives its popular online chatbot, ChatGPT.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Two More ‘Succession’ Actors Are Broadway Bound, in ‘Job’
description: Peter Friedman and Sydney Lemmon will star in the two-hander, a psychological thriller that previously found success downtown.
content: “Job,” a two-character thriller about a psychological evaluation going awry, started small, with a run last year at SoHo Playhouse. Word-of-mouth was good, the New York Times review was positive and sales were strong, so early this year it transferred for another Off Broadway run at the Connelly Theater in the East Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Flaco the Owl’s Wings to Be Kept at a Museum in His Neighborhood
description: Remains from the Eurasian eagle-owl, whose year on the loose captivated New York City, will become part of collections at the American Museum of Natural History.
content: Partial remains of Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl whose escape from the Central Park Zoo and year on the loose enthralled New York City before his death in February, will be kept at a museum near where he spent most of his life, zoo officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Lawyers Assail Limited Gag Order Request in Documents Case
description: The latest battle over what the former president can say about a continuing legal case came after he falsely suggested that F.B.I. agents were authorized to shoot him when they searched Mar-a-Lago.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers on Monday assailed a request by federal prosecutors to limit what he could say about a new flare-up in a case accusing him of illegally retaining classified documents after leaving office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Elon Musk Dominates Space Launch. Rivals Are Calling Foul.
description: At a time when the U.S. government is concerned about its reliance on a mercurial billionaire for access to space, new competitors say Elon Musk’s SpaceX is using tactics intended to squash them.
content: Elon Musk aggressively elbowed his way into the space launch business over the past two decades, combining engineering genius and an entrepreneurial drive with a demand that the U.S. government stop favoring the big, slow-moving contractors that had long dominated the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Apologizes After Reports That He Used an Anti-Gay Slur
description: Francis’ remark came as he spoke against admitting gay men to seminaries during what was supposed to be a closed-door meeting with Italian bishops last week.
content: The Vatican said on Tuesday that Pope Francis “extends his apologies” after reports that he used an offensive slang word referring to gay men at what was intended to be a private meeting with 250 Italian bishops last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Ted Cruz Has Some Strong Opinions About College Sports
description: Money is changing college sports in big and small ways. Jane Coaston interviews Ted Cruz about how some conservatives want to regulate college athletics.
content: College sports bring in billions of dollars in revenue every year, but until very recently virtually none of it went to athletes. In 2021, the Supreme Court ruled in N.C.A.A. v. Alston that student athletes should be able to profit from their names, images or likenesses, known as NIL. As Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted in a concurring opinion, the N.C.A.A.’s policies against permitting athletes to profit from their labor could be considered a violation of antitrust laws, writing, “Nowhere else in America can businesses get away with agreeing not to pay their workers a fair-market rate on the theory that their product is defined by not paying their workers a fair-market rate.” Since then, in practice, NIL has included two common types of compensation: endorsement deals for athletes, but also more direct payments, which usually come from college-affiliated collectives supported by donors in exchange for appearances at events, social media posts or other promotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: More of the Best Books About California
description: We’re adding love letters and cautionary tales to our Golden State reading list.
content: One of my favorite books about Los Angeles is Eve Babitz’s witty collection of essays “Slow Days, Fast Company.” The first time I read it, a few years ago, while living in L.A., I was struck by how a book published in 1977 — telling bold and sharply observed stories of L.A.’s bohemian artist class — could still ring true so many years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Big Oil’s Winning Streak Forces Activist Investors to Regroup
description: Climate-focused shareholders are rethinking their tactics ahead of this week’s annual meetings at Exxon Mobil and Chevron.
content: Months of tensions between oil majors and activist investors could reach a boiling point at the annual meetings of Exxon Mobil and Chevron Wednesday, as the U.S. giants pump record levels of crude and sit on bumper profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Need a Refresher on Trump’s Criminal Trial? Catch Up Here.
description: Donald J. Trump has been charged with 34 felony counts in the first criminal case against an American president. Defense lawyers and prosecutors are making their closing arguments on Tuesday.
content: Closing arguments began Tuesday in the weekslong criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, the first president to face prosecution in American history, in a case that stems from a hush-money deal to a porn star who said she had sex with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
title: Why Lawmakers Are Brawling and People Are Protesting in Taiwan
description: Supporters of President Lai Ching-te are protesting legislative amendments introduced by the opposition that would limit his authority.
content: Opposition lawmakers in Taiwan pushed through measures on Tuesday that could challenge the powers of the new president, Lai Ching-te, defying tens of thousands of his supporters who poured into the streets in recent days in protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: Senators See Possible Conflicts of Interest in Health Care Pricing Tools
description: A data analytics firm that helps insurers collect big fees while leaving some patients with unpaid bills has been summoned to explain its business model.
content: The chairmen of two Senate committees overseeing health policy, concerned about companies “padding their own profits” at the expense of patients, are looking into the practices of a data analytics firm that works with big insurers to cut payments to medical providers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: Adam Neumann Gives Up on Buying Back WeWork
description: The co-founder of the shared-office company, who stepped down under pressure before the firm went bankrupt, announced an audacious takeover bid this year.
content: Adam Neumann has officially admitted defeat in his quest to buy back WeWork, ending his bid to acquire the co-working company, which he helped found in 2010 and built into a global enterprise valued at $47 billion before it fell into bankruptcy last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Jaap van Zweden’s Brief, Fraught Time Atop the New York Philharmonic
description: He arrived on a mission to reshape the ensemble as its music director. Now, as he departs, he’s still making sense of his pandemic-interrupted tenure.
content: On a balmy spring morning, after a breakfast of coffee and plain yogurt at a luxury Manhattan hotel, Jaap van Zweden grabbed his bag of conducting batons and scores by Mozart and Gubaidulina and set out for Lincoln Center through the wilds of Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 12 Movies and Shows Before They Leave Netflix in June
description: Mark Wahlberg and Reese Witherspoon when they were kids-ish, Clint Eastwood as a drug mule on the other side of life, and Meryl Streep in “Out of Africa.”
content: One of the most durable shows of the modern television era leaves Netflix in the United States this month, along with an equally long-lasting horror franchise, a handful of enjoyable genre flicks and several Oscar winners and nominees. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jodi Kantor, Mooj Zadie, Eric Krupke, Luke Vander Ploeg, Michael Benoist, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Alitos and Their Flags
description: The saga of a Supreme Court justice, his wife and two symbols adopted by people campaigning to overturn the result of the 2020 election.
content: The discovery that an upside-down American flag — a symbol adopted by the campaign to overturn the 2020 election result — had flown at the home of Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. elicited concerns from politicians, legal scholars and others. And then came news of a second flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Schulte and Katie Benner
title: ‘I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It.’ Tornado Devastates Arkansas Town.
description: Rogers, Ark., was one of many places hit hard by the rash of storms over Memorial Day weekend across the South.
content: Melisa Swearingen woke up early on Sunday morning as a tornado bore down on her home in the northwestern corner of Arkansas. As she raced down the stairs with her toddler, she looked out the window and saw a 40-foot tree falling toward the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Georgia’s Ruling Party Secures a Contentious Law on Foreign Influence
description: The Parliament, controlled by the Georgian Dream party, overrode a presidential veto of a bill critics say could undermine the country’s efforts to join the European Union.
content: Georgia’s Parliament overrode a presidential veto to give final approval on Tuesday evening to a contentious bill that has plunged the country into a political crisis and threatened to derail the pro-Western aspirations of many Georgians in favor of closer ties with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Want to Succeed as an Artist? Click Here.
description: With a rising number of artists vying for a limited number of galleries and grants, arts professionals are pivoting to careers as coaches. But can they help people profit from their talents?
content: From 2005 to 2017, Paddy Johnson ran a respected art-world blog, Art F City. “Fiercely Independent,” began its tagline. But art criticism is a precarious business. She tried teaching as an adjunct, but that wasn’t much better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: China’s Role in Ukraine
description: Russia has been able to keep paying for the war, despite sanctions. How? U.S. officials point to Beijing.
content: Over the last few weeks, a Russian blitz has claimed more than a dozen villages in northeast Ukraine, near the country’s second-largest city. This summer, Russia will likely continue its offensive push in the country’s east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: The Daily Beast’s New Bosses Plan Buyouts to Cut Losses
description: The two leaders have looked for money-saving measures since joining the digital tabloid in April.
content: The Daily Beast’s new leaders will do a round of voluntary buyouts intended to cut costs by $1.5 million, in one of their first major moves to try to revitalize the flagging digital tabloid.
source.name: The New York Times
